comments.body: I've seen this `binding @ _` pattern a few times but I'm not sure I understand this. Why not just `_`?
readibility. This way you know which parameter is ignored.
This wasn't in a shutdown hook before. Did something change or am I missing something?

Nothing changed but before we didn‚Äôt do any attempts at clean shutdown outside of Console. Rather than dropping that logic completely, moving it to a shutdown hook seemed more sensible so we use it for the web server.

`PartyState` looks like an innocent class but it actually carries around a whole thread pool (this is where I was seeing leaks). Therefore, this is now no longer part of the config (parsing a config file shouldn‚Äôt create a thread pool) and we only create it when we spin up the corresponding actor.

This is a slight change, you no longer get the list of parties if you‚Äôre not connected. That seems acceptable to me. The login will fail anyway. We could consider having an autorefresh but that seems like something for a separate PR.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +88,92 @@      onSuccess(getAppState()) {
        case ApplicationStateConnecting(_, _, _, _) =>
          complete(SignIn(SignInSelect(Set.empty), Some(NotConnected)))
        case ApplicationStateConnected(_, _, _, _, _, _, partyActors) =>
          complete(SignIn(SignInSelect(partyActors.keySet), None))

comments.body: Another slight difference. The login will now fail if the actor is unresponsive. If that‚Äôs the case, nothing will work anyway so I‚Äôd almost call that a bugfix.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +138,142 @@                                case Store.PartyActorUnresponsive =>
                                  complete(
                                    SignIn(SignInSelect(partyActors.keySet), Some(Unresponsive)))
                              }
                            case None =>

comments.body: I'm wondering whether we should put this logic into the general daml.yaml (or rather daml-project-config) library?

`daml-project-config` is about the project-specific configuration, if we make a library of it it should be something different. Since I'll for sure need this piece of code to make Extractor work with authentication I'd suggest we defer it to that contribution. Sounds good?
